etn 0.1.0.9106

  • Reference

Access ETN data using the etn R package

Stijn Van Hoey

2020-03-12

Source: vignettes/etn.Rmd
etn.Rmd

Introduction

The etn package provides a set of get_*-based functions to access the ETN data and metadata. In this vignette a quick overview of these main functions is given. As the access to data is linked to specific user profiles, keep in mind that the results can be different for other users.

To start, load the package:

library(etn)

When not installed, do not forget to install the package using the devtools package:

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("inbo/etn")

The database connection

In order to access the data, the first step is always to connect with your user credentials (as received by VLIZ) to the database.

con <- connect_to_etn(Sys.getenv("userid"), Sys.getenv("pwd"))

Remark that for this example, we load the user credentials as environmental variables by saving an .Renviron file in the home directory with the username and password stored. Other options are available as well, as explained here.

Once the connection established, the get_* functions can be used to effectively access the data. Each of these functions have a (valid database) connection as first input.

Notice, that you can find the get_*-functions inside Rstudio by typing: etn::get_* + TAB button.

Metadata

Project overview

To get a full overview of the projects you have access to, use the function get_projects():

my_projects <- get_projects(con)
head(my_projects, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 13
#>       pk project_code project_type application_type telemetry_type
#>    <int> <chr>        <chr>        <chr>            <chr>         
#>  1   638 cpod-lifewa… network      cpod             <NA>          
#>  2     3 lifewatch    network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  3   617 pc4c         network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  4   625 Deveron      network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  5   626 MorayFirth   network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  6   627 Aberdeen     network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  7   628 Conon        network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  8   629 Skye         network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  9   599 homarus      animal       acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#> 10   632 OTN          animal       acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#> # … with 8 more variables: project_name <chr>,
#> #   principal_investigator <chr>, start_date <date>, end_date <date>,
#> #   latitude <dbl>, longitude <dbl>, moratorium <chr>,
#> #   imis_dataset_id <int>

As projects are defined both on the level of the animal as well as the network, a column type is available that defines the type of project (animal or network). Still, one can also directly subset by adding the type as input argument, e.g. for network:

my_network_projects <- get_projects(con, project_type = "network")
head(my_network_projects, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 13
#>       pk project_code project_type application_type telemetry_type
#>    <int> <chr>        <chr>        <chr>            <chr>         
#>  1   638 cpod-lifewa… network      cpod             <NA>          
#>  2     3 lifewatch    network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  3   617 pc4c         network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  4   625 Deveron      network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  5   626 MorayFirth   network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  6   627 Aberdeen     network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  7   628 Conon        network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  8   629 Skye         network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#>  9    13 maas         network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#> 10    12 dijle        network      acoustic_teleme… <NA>          
#> # … with 8 more variables: project_name <chr>,
#> #   principal_investigator <chr>, start_date <date>, end_date <date>,
#> #   latitude <dbl>, longitude <dbl>, moratorium <chr>,
#> #   imis_dataset_id <int>

Receiver overview

A network project typically considers multiple receivers that are placed on specific locations to lay out the network. To get an overview of receivers deployments linked to specific projects, use the get_deployments function:

ws3_deployments <- get_deployments(con, network_project_code = "ws3")
head(ws3_deployments, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 6 x 40
#>      pk receiver_id application_type network_project… station_name
#>   <int> <chr>       <chr>            <chr>            <chr>       
#> 1  6173 VR2W-127731 acoustic_teleme… ws3              ws-53A      
#> 2  6177 VR2W-127725 acoustic_teleme… ws3              ws-HW6      
#> 3  6178 VR2W-127735 acoustic_teleme… ws3              ws-42A      
#> 4  6179 VR2W-127734 acoustic_teleme… ws3              ws-55       
#> 5  6180 VR2W-127737 acoustic_teleme… ws3              ws-53       
#> 6  6182 VR2W-115439 acoustic_teleme… ws3              ws-F42      
#> # … with 35 more variables: station_description <chr>,
#> #   station_manager <chr>, deploy_date_time <dttm>, deploy_latitude <dbl>,
#> #   deploy_longitude <dbl>, intended_latitude <dbl>,
#> #   intended_longitude <dbl>, mooring_type <chr>, bottom_depth <chr>,
#> #   riser_length <chr>, deploy_depth <chr>,
#> #   battery_installation_date <dttm>, battery_estimated_end_date <dttm>,
#> #   activation_date_time <dttm>, recover_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   recover_latitude <dbl>, recover_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   download_date_time <dttm>, download_file_name <chr>,
#> #   valid_data_until_date_time <dttm>, sync_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   time_drift <chr>, ar_battery_installation_date <dttm>,
#> #   ar_confirm <chr>, transmit_profile <chr>, transmit_power_output <chr>,
#> #   log_temperature_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_temperature_sample_period <int>, log_tilt_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_noise_stats_period <int>, log_noise_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_depth_stats_period <int>, log_depth_sample_period <int>,
#> #   comments <chr>, receiver_status <chr>

You can also define multiple (network) projects at the same time, by combining them in a vector:

ws_deployments <- get_deployments(con, network_project_code = c("ws1", "ws3"))
head(ws_deployments, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 40
#>       pk receiver_id application_type network_project… station_name
#>    <int> <chr>       <chr>            <chr>            <chr>       
#>  1  3978 VR2W-123826 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-W7       
#>  2  6020 VR2W-123815 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-W6       
#>  3  6026 VR2W-123832 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-OG10     
#>  4  6029 VR2Tx-4807… acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-W7       
#>  5  6030 VR2Tx-4800… acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-WN2      
#>  6  6032 VR2Tx-4807… acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-DL12     
#>  7  6033 VR2W-123831 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-OGDL     
#>  8  6036 VR2W-123819 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-SP3      
#>  9  6038 VR2W-123821 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-GVWSP    
#> 10  6039 VR2W-131002 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-TRAWL    
#> # … with 35 more variables: station_description <chr>,
#> #   station_manager <chr>, deploy_date_time <dttm>, deploy_latitude <dbl>,
#> #   deploy_longitude <dbl>, intended_latitude <dbl>,
#> #   intended_longitude <dbl>, mooring_type <chr>, bottom_depth <chr>,
#> #   riser_length <chr>, deploy_depth <chr>,
#> #   battery_installation_date <dttm>, battery_estimated_end_date <dttm>,
#> #   activation_date_time <dttm>, recover_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   recover_latitude <dbl>, recover_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   download_date_time <dttm>, download_file_name <chr>,
#> #   valid_data_until_date_time <dttm>, sync_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   time_drift <chr>, ar_battery_installation_date <dttm>,
#> #   ar_confirm <chr>, transmit_profile <chr>, transmit_power_output <chr>,
#> #   log_temperature_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_temperature_sample_period <int>, log_tilt_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_noise_stats_period <int>, log_noise_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_depth_stats_period <int>, log_depth_sample_period <int>,
#> #   comments <chr>, receiver_status <chr>

When a number of columns is not useful to your specific purpose, remember that the output is a data.frame, which can be filtered and subsetted conveniently with for example the dplyr functions.

library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

For example, selecting only the columns serial_number, receiver and status:

ws_deployments %>% 
  select(receiver_id, receiver_status) %>%
  head(10)  # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 2
#>    receiver_id  receiver_status
#>    <chr>        <chr>          
#>  1 VR2W-123826  Lost           
#>  2 VR2W-123815  Active         
#>  3 VR2W-123832  Active         
#>  4 VR2Tx-480722 Active         
#>  5 VR2Tx-480061 Active         
#>  6 VR2Tx-480720 Active         
#>  7 VR2W-123831  Active         
#>  8 VR2W-123819  Active         
#>  9 VR2W-123821  Available      
#> 10 VR2W-131002  Active

Deployments overview

Receivers are deployed for a specific period and this deployment information can be accessed as well with the command get_deployments. Filtering on the network project is similar to get_receivers and as the information about the receiver status is crucial, the function provides an additional argument to query based on the receiver status. Getting an overview of the lost and broken receivers of a specific project:

my_deployments <- get_deployments(con, network_project_code = "ws1", 
                                  receiver_status = c("Broken", "Lost"))
head(my_deployments, 10) # print 10 first 
#> # A tibble: 1 x 40
#>      pk receiver_id application_type network_project… station_name
#>   <int> <chr>       <chr>            <chr>            <chr>       
#> 1  3978 VR2W-123826 acoustic_teleme… ws1              ws-W7       
#> # … with 35 more variables: station_description <chr>,
#> #   station_manager <chr>, deploy_date_time <dttm>, deploy_latitude <dbl>,
#> #   deploy_longitude <dbl>, intended_latitude <dbl>,
#> #   intended_longitude <dbl>, mooring_type <chr>, bottom_depth <chr>,
#> #   riser_length <chr>, deploy_depth <chr>,
#> #   battery_installation_date <dttm>, battery_estimated_end_date <dttm>,
#> #   activation_date_time <dttm>, recover_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   recover_latitude <dbl>, recover_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   download_date_time <dttm>, download_file_name <chr>,
#> #   valid_data_until_date_time <dttm>, sync_date_time <dttm>,
#> #   time_drift <chr>, ar_battery_installation_date <dttm>,
#> #   ar_confirm <chr>, transmit_profile <chr>, transmit_power_output <chr>,
#> #   log_temperature_stats_period <int>,
#> #   log_temperature_sample_period <int>, log_tilt_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_noise_stats_period <int>, log_noise_sample_period <int>,
#> #   log_depth_stats_period <int>, log_depth_sample_period <int>,
#> #   comments <chr>, receiver_status <chr>

Animals overview

Within an animal project, multiple animals are provided with a transmitter. The metadata of these animals is requested with the function get_animals. As animals can be part of both network and animal projects, both can be used to filter the results.

As such, selecting the animals metadata for the 2012_leopoldkanaal project:

my_animals <- get_animals(con, animal_project_code = "2012_leopoldkanaal")
head(my_animals, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 63
#>       pk animal_id animal_project_… scientific_name common_name aphia_id
#>    <int> <chr>     <chr>            <chr>           <chr>          <int>
#>  1   229 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  2   230 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  3   231 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  4   232 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  5   387 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  6   388 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  7   390 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  8   391 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#>  9   392 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#> 10   393 <NA>      2012_leopoldkan… Anguilla angui… European e…       NA
#> # … with 57 more variables: animal_nickname <chr>,
#> #   capture_date_time <dttm>, capture_location <chr>,
#> #   capture_latitude <dbl>, capture_longitude <dbl>, capture_method <chr>,
#> #   capture_depth <chr>, capture_temperature_change <chr>,
#> #   release_date_time <dttm>, release_location <chr>,
#> #   release_latitude <dbl>, release_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   recapture_date_time <dttm>, length1_type <chr>, length1 <dbl>,
#> #   length1_unit <chr>, length2_type <chr>, length2 <dbl>,
#> #   length2_unit <chr>, length3_type <chr>, length3 <dbl>,
#> #   length3_unit <chr>, length4_type <chr>, length4 <dbl>,
#> #   length4_unit <chr>, weight <dbl>, weight_unit <chr>, age <dbl>,
#> #   age_unit <chr>, sex <chr>, life_stage <chr>, wild_or_hatchery <chr>,
#> #   stock <chr>, surgery_date_time <dttm>, surgery_location <chr>,
#> #   surgery_latitude <dbl>, surgery_longitude <dbl>, treatment_type <chr>,
#> #   dna_sample <chr>, sedative <chr>, sedative_concentration <chr>,
#> #   anaesthetic <chr>, buffer <chr>, anaesthetic_concentration <chr>,
#> #   buffer_concentration_in_anaesthetic <chr>,
#> #   anaesthetic_concentration_in_recirculation <chr>,
#> #   buffer_concentration_in_recirculation <chr>, dissolved_oxygen <chr>,
#> #   pre_surgery_holding_period <chr>, post_surgery_holding_period <chr>,
#> #   holding_temperature <chr>, comments <chr>, tag_id <chr>, tag_fk <chr>,
#> #   tagger <chr>, tagging_type <chr>, tagging_methodology <chr>

When interested in specific species, add the scientific name as argument.

my_animals <- get_animals(con, animal_project_code = "phd_reubens",
                       scientific_name = "Sentinel")
head(my_animals, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 63
#>       pk animal_id animal_project_… scientific_name common_name aphia_id
#>    <int> <chr>     <chr>            <chr>           <chr>          <int>
#>  1   733 S01       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#>  2   734 S02       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA

#>  4   736 S04       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#>  5   737 S05       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#>  6   738 S06       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#>  7   739 S07       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#>  8   740 S08       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#>  9   741 S09       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#> 10   742 S10       phd_reubens      Sentinel        <NA>              NA
#> # … with 57 more variables: animal_nickname <chr>,
#> #   capture_date_time <dttm>, capture_location <chr>,
#> #   capture_latitude <dbl>, capture_longitude <dbl>, capture_method <chr>,
#> #   capture_depth <chr>, capture_temperature_change <chr>,
#> #   release_date_time <dttm>, release_location <chr>,

#> #   recapture_date_time <dttm>, length1_type <chr>, length1 <dbl>,

#> #   pre_surgery_holding_period <chr>, post_surgery_holding_period <chr>,

#> #   tagger <chr>, tagging_type <chr>, tagging_methodology <chr>

Remark: currently these names are NOT yet verified with a taxonomic backbone as this is not yet done for the names of the database managed by VLIZ. Support will be added when the database names are as well.

Transmitter overview

The transmitters/tags metadata can be accessed by the get_tags function:

my_tags <- get_tags(con)
head(my_tags, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 45
#>       pk tag_id tag_id_alternat… telemetry_type manufacturer model
#>    <int> <chr>  <chr>            <chr>          <chr>        <chr>
#>  1  1883 A69-9… <NA>             acoustic       VEMCO        V13A…
#>  2  3582 S256-… A69-1105-57      Acoustic       THELMA       T-MP…
#>  3  2391 R64K-… A69-1303-1242    acoustic tag   THELMA       LP-7…
#>  4  2435 R64K-… A69-1303-2372    acoustic tag   THELMA       ID-L…
#>  5  1802 A69-9… <NA>             acoustic       VEMCO        V13A…
#>  6  1447 A69-1… <NA>             acoustic       VEMCO        V13-…
#>  7   284 A69-1… <NA>             Acoustic       VEMCO        V13-…
#>  8  3074 A69-9… <NA>             acoustic       VEMCO        V13A…
#>  9  3248 A69-1… <NA>             acoustic       VEMCO        V13  
#> 10  3497 S256-… A69-1105-99      acoustic       THELMA       ADT-…
#> # … with 39 more variables: frequency <chr>, type <chr>,
#> #   serial_number <chr>, tag_id_protocol <chr>, tag_id_code <chr>,
#> #   status <chr>, activation_date <dttm>, battery_estimated_life <chr>,
#> #   battery_estimated_end_date <dttm>, sensor_type <chr>,
#> #   sensor_slope <dbl>, sensor_intercept <dbl>, sensor_range <chr>,
#> #   sensor_transmit_ratio <int>, accelerometer_algorithm <chr>,
#> #   accelerometer_samples_per_second <int>, owner_organization <chr>,
#> #   owner_pi <chr>, financing_project <chr>, step1_min_delay <chr>,
#> #   step1_max_delay <chr>, step1_power <chr>, step1_duration <int>,
#> #   step1_acceleration_duration <int>, step2_min_delay <chr>,
#> #   step2_max_delay <chr>, step2_power <chr>, step2_duration <int>,
#> #   step2_acceleration_duration <int>, step3_min_delay <chr>,
#> #   step3_max_delay <chr>, step3_power <chr>, step3_duration <int>,
#> #   step3_acceleration_duration <int>, step4_min_delay <chr>,
#> #   step4_max_delay <chr>, step4_power <chr>, step4_duration <int>,
#> #   step4_acceleration_duration <int>

Detections data

The raw detections are the core for any type of analysis and access is provided by the get_detections function. Different filters are available which you can explore by typing ?get_detections in the console. To narrow down the data request, filters are provided on animal/network project name, the deployment station name and the transmitter identifier to narrow. Furthermore, as these data sets can be large, some additional time-based filters are provided with a start_date and an end_date:

my_detections <- get_detections(con, animal_project_code = "phd_reubens", 
                                start_date = "2011-01-28", end_date = "2011-02-01")
head(my_detections, 10) # print 10 first
#> # A tibble: 10 x 24
#>        pk date_time           receiver_id application_type network_project…
#>     <int> <dttm>              <chr>       <chr>            <chr>           
#>  1 1.92e7 2011-01-31 16:44:19 VR2W-110784 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  2 1.92e7 2011-01-31 16:54:23 VR2W-110784 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  3 1.94e7 2011-01-28 05:35:14 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  4 1.94e7 2011-01-28 11:07:22 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  5 1.94e7 2011-01-28 11:17:26 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  6 1.94e7 2011-01-28 11:37:33 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  7 1.94e7 2011-01-28 11:47:37 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  8 1.94e7 2011-01-28 11:57:41 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#>  9 1.94e7 2011-01-28 12:07:45 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#> 10 1.94e7 2011-01-28 12:17:49 VR2W-106253 acoustic_teleme… thornton        
#> # … with 19 more variables: tag_id <chr>, tag_fk <int>, animal_id <chr>,
#> #   animal_fk <int>, animal_project_code <chr>, scientific_name <chr>,
#> #   station_name <chr>, deploy_latitude <dbl>, deploy_longitude <dbl>,
#> #   sensor_type <chr>, sensor_value <dbl>, sensor_unit <chr>,
#> #   sensor_value_depth <dbl>, sensor_value_acceleration <dbl>,
#> #   sensor_value_temperature <chr>, signal_to_noise_ratio <int>,
#> #   source_file <chr>, qc_flag <chr>, deployment_fk <int>

The date level can be defined on month (e.g. "2011-01") or year (e.g. "2011") level as well. Finally, for explorative reasons, a hard maximum limit of records to request can help to have a quick glance on the expected data.

See more exampled in the function help (remember the ?get_detections).
